fields.description:
Currently working in a moderate sized Stash instance (770+ users, ~60 Projects). Administration is becoming difficult, especially regarding seeing who has permissions in which project, repo, and branch. 

Having the Stash directory contain information regarding what projects, repos, and branches users have explicit permissions. This would be great if it also included group permissions (if in group, and group has permissions, show that user has permissions). This would simplify checking permissions.
fields.summary: Show permissions in User Directory

fields.description:
This is a perennial problem for any software program that has permissions.

Let's say I'm an admin. I have special powers so I can keep things running smoothly. Great. 

Now I want to test that the permissions people have are correct. But I can't see things as they do, I have my special powers so I can access a bunch of things, and I won't see the limitations of "normal" accounts.

The simplest way for me to get around this, is if I could create two accounts for myself, one with special powers and one without, so I login as my "normal" account for everyday work and as my "admin" account for the admin stuff. But then I use up two licenses.

Any way you guys could enable admin accounts to log in with either "normal" or "admin" privileges? Or at least allow admin accounts to also have a normal account that doesn't count against the license limits?
fields.summary: Allow bimodal login for admins (full or normal privileges)

fields.description:
Here is our use case :

* The master branch is the official branch and we set a commit rule that allow only the lead developer / architect to commit.
* To be able to push their modifications, the developers need to create a feature branch and create a pull request when the code is ready to be reviewed and merged.

So here is the problem when the master has not changed (see screen1.png) :

# The pull request is created to merge from the feature/branch to the master. The diff is good and it shows the related commits (see screen2.png);
# After the pull request is created, if we review it, there is no change because the feature/branch is ahead of master (see screen3.png);
# When the merge is done, nothing happens. Worst, if the option to close the branch after the merge is checked, the code is lost.

This is not viable if you want to restrain code from being pushed to branches directly.
fields.summary: Pull request won't merge change from ahead branch

fields.description: After upgrading Stash from 3.6.0 to 3.8.0 we seeing an issue with custom look and feel. Whenever a site is refreshed or a new page is opened a default blue bar with default logo is being displayed for a second, followed by customized look and feel which loads second later.
fields.summary: Menu bar switches to original colours when site is refreshed

fields.description: There seems to be an inconsistency in how long a repository name is. It's 128 characters when creating a new repository and only 64 characters when forking a project. Is this intentional and is there a reason to have a cap for repository names? We have somewhat long names to determine the origin as well as the feature of the repository so we would really like to have the opportunity to increase the default max :)
fields.summary: Inconsistent max length for repository name

fields.description: the head stash logo href to http://127.0.0.1:7990
fields.summary: head left logo link to wrong address

fields.description:
I must be missing something really obvious.

Let's say I have a codebase with five files:

     foo.c
     foo.h
     bar.c
     bar.h
     baz.c

I have been changing `bar.c` and `foo.c` relentlessly over the last 20 commits or so.

Now I want to have a code review of the entire codebase.

*Where is the place where my team can enter comments for any file?* It looks like they can easily comment on files that have changed in a particular commit. But they can't comment on other files that exist (but have not changed) in a particular commit.

The "Source" navigation tab allows you to browse the entire codebase, but not comment on any of it.
fields.summary: How can I comment on any code, not just code that has changed in a commit?

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of Aug 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hi everyone,

Thank you for your feedback on this issue. From [Bitbucket Server and Data Center 7.4|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-7-4-release-notes-1013849643.html] onwards you will see an option in your _account settings_ to disable the keyboard shortcuts. Click on your avatar on top right and then click on _Manage account_ to see the option.

Cheers,
 Imran Khan
 Product Manager - Bitbucket Server and Data Center

*Original description:*

It would be great if users had a way to disable keyboard shortcuts in stash. Some people prefer to use the browser find features over the javascript stash find box. It would be awesome if the user could click the help menu -> keyboard shortcuts then click disable shortcuts similar to confluence [confluence|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Keyboard+Shortcuts#KeyboardShortcuts-Disablingandre-enablingkeyboardshortcuts] or [jira|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA063/Using+Keyboard+Shortcuts#UsingKeyboardShortcuts-DisablingandRe-enablingKeyboardShortcuts].
fields.summary: Disable keyboard shortcuts

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

If you have a large repository containing binary files merges often take longer than a minute. The error "Server Unreachable" is given even though the merge is still occurring behind the scenes. 

Description on https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASHKB/Server+Unreachable+-+Timeout+when+merging+or+viewing+Diff+of+pull+request

h3. Cause

The server allows the merge up to 5m (configurable) to complete and the UI (not configurable) would have to be willing to wait the same amount of time the server is willing to wait but it is currently hard-coded (1 minute).

h3. Suggested Solution

It would be good to have a more informative message for these cases, or at least the ability to turn off the error message so that developers don't think that something has gone wrong. A loading bar for these large merges would be ideal.
fields.summary: Front end for pull request merges should wait as long as server does for process to complete

fields.description:
Hi,

Would like to know if any feature available to add a group of people directly while creating a PR and also want to check if peer to peer reviewers can be added? Suppose if X developer is creating a PR request, it should automatically tie Y person as a reviewer.

I also want to know if any command line utility to create PRs from terminal?

Regards,
Srini
fields.summary: Reviewers group in Pull Requests creation and also adding peer reviewers?

fields.description: We use git flow for our workflow, and so usually merge our pull requests via command line instead of using the Stash GUI. When I merge a feature branch into the development branch and push, my pull request gets marked as "Declined" in Stash. This happens for me every time (I am a Linux (Ubuntu) user, using git 2.1.4 with default settings) but not for the colleagues that are using Mac.
fields.summary: Pull request marked as declined when merged via command-line git

fields.description:
My suggestion is a disapprove button for a pull request.

It would remove the pull request from the list of pull requests in the inbox.

There should be a repo setting option to automatically remove a pull request disapproval when the pull request is updated with a new commit, which would bring the pull request back into the inbox.
fields.summary: Disapprove pull request

fields.description:
Currently when looking at the list of SSH Keys in a repository it's only possible to see the first few characters of it. The suggestion is to be able to fully view it, including being able to copy it.

*For those interested in checking the keys, there are still two ways of doing this*:
# Hover the key with the mouse pointer, so the full key will be shown.
# Use REST API functions to retrieve the keys for projects and repositories:
#* For project: GET method of the function [/rest/keys/1.0/projects/\{projectKey\}/ssh|https://developer.atlassian.com/static/rest/bitbucket-server/4.5.2/bitbucket-ssh-rest.html#idp308112]
#* For repository: GET method of the function [/rest/keys/1.0/projects/\{projectKey\}/repos/\{repositorySlug\}/ssh|https://developer.atlassian.com/static/rest/bitbucket-server/4.5.2/bitbucket-ssh-rest.html#idp330368]
fields.summary: View full SSH key in access keys

fields.description:
I have pull requests that I created and have been merged. I would like to be able see these pull requests. Currently once a pull request is merged there's no way to find it.

The ask is a feature to see pull requests (merged or otherwise) for a given user, or at least for myself.
fields.summary: Need ability to see pull requests that I've created

fields.description: Stash pull request in diff mode. Text is wide enough necessitating horizontal scrolling. For some reason the horizontal scrollbar doesn't appear until scrolling down a bit (see attached). Thus in order to scroll right, I have to first scroll down then to the right, very cumbersome. If there's clipped content, the scrollbar should always appear (without the user have to do additional scrolling in the tangental direction).
fields.summary: Horizontal scrollbar doesn't appear until scrolling down

fields.description:
I'm a project admin but not a Stash admin. We have been encouraged to use groups rather than users for permissions... but I can't see group membership, and I need to be able to verify who's in a group.

Is there any way you can add the ability to see group membership to project admins? I don't need to add/remove users to groups, but I do need to verify who's in the group.
fields.summary: Permissions audit: see group membership

fields.description:
I have a project with some sensitive repositories and a non-sensitive respository. I need to provide read access to the non-sensitive repository to a user, but he needs to NOT have access to the sensitive repositories.

I got this working, but only after accidentally opening the project up to any logged-in user, and I did not realize this until I was able to request a test user to be created so I could log in as the test user and see what repositories were accessible.

The permissions management would be a LOT easier to verify if you could just see what a particular user sees.
fields.summary: Permissions audit: allow project admin to review effective permissions for a particular user

fields.description: When in a pull request, I click the "Jira Issues" link and the JIRA popup comes up.  I click on the "More" button to access more workflow actions, but the dropdown itself is hidden under the popup and I'm unable to select anything in the dropdown.  This seems to have started happening ever since we upgraded to 3.8.0.
fields.summary: Workflow actions "More" drop-down in Jira Pop-Up is hidden by the pop up

fields.description: Currently automerge will show a conflict warning in the pull request if there is a conflict going to the branch that is being merged into.  It does not however show any conflicts that will happen as the merge continues up the version tree.  This can be manually done by before hand to verify if you will get a conflict but that is tedious and it would be nice if stash could do test merges all the way to master and display that warning in the pull request before merge.
fields.summary: Show automerge conflicts in pull request
CSS Style is setting table's width to 0; Messing up README.md tables on FF and IE11

fields.description:
As shown in the screenshot, a user can undo an approved pull request. Currently the language is:

John UNAPPROVED the pull request.

"UNAPPROVED" is grammatically not used correctly in this sense. Refer to the discussion here: http://forum.wordreference.com/showthread.php?t=2767115

Potential alternatives are:
John marked the pull request as UNAPPROVED
John changed the pull request to UNAPPROVED
John CANCELED the pull request approval
John REVERTED the pull request approval

!https://s3.amazonaws.com/uploads.hipchat.com/7413/1074901/mORbWNpkjr2xz81/upload.png!
fields.summary: "UNAPPROVED" is grammatically uncorrect

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When you have a proxy required to access to Stash (ngnx, apache, etc) but you also must define a different corporate proxy to access the internet (for the Marketplace) by adding the corporate proxy details to JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS variable in /bin/setenv.sh this causes Application links to fail.

h3. Steps to Duplicate
- Setup Stash to work with a proxy (http/https don't seem to be a factor)  Users point to address http://stash.company.com which is the Proxy that forwards request to http://stashserver:7990.  This works fine and Application Links are able to be created without issue but if you require a Proxy to gain access to the internet the Marketplace will not function
- Edit setenv.sh and add the following to the JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS
{code}
-Dhttp.proxyHost=proxy.host 
-Dhttp.proxyPort=80 
-Dhttp.nonProxyHost=localhost\|*.internaladdress.com 
-Dhttps.proxyHost=proxy.host 
-Dhttps.proxyPort=80
{code}
- Restart Stash
- Now the Marketplace is available but all of the application links fail.
- Edit setenv.sh, remove any proxy related options from the JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS variable in /bin/setenv.sh
- While still in setenv.sh, scroll down to the JAVA_OPTS= variable
-- In the JAVA_OPTS variable add the Java proxy options before the end quote
- Restart Stash
- Now the Marketplace is still available but all of the application links fail
- Edit setenv.sh, remove any references to the corporate proxy for accessing the internet from the JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS  and the  JAVA_OPTS
- Restart Stash
- Now the Application links work but access to the Marketplace understandably does not work because the Stash server has no access to the Internet.

h3. Expected Behavior
Stash should be able to work with an internal proxy\reverse proxy that manages traffic to the Stash Server and Stash should be able to simultaneously be able to communicate with the Internet using an established corporate proxy that is most likely not the same proxy.
fields.summary: When Stash uses Proxy for users to access but needs proxy for external internet access Application Links fail

fields.description: The suggestion is to allow an Administrator to merge a pull request that requires a minimum number of approvers even if this number is not attended, i.e. a pull request requires 2 approvers; it has 0 approvers; a Stash user can't merge the pull request, but an Administrator could be able to do so.
fields.summary: Allow administrator to merge pull request ignoring number of approvers

fields.description:
STASH-3352 introduced a regression in the throttling of hosting operations for SSH, which means that the git clone/fetch/push operations over SSH are not being throttled at all.

This can lead to high memory/cpu usage, swapping and general thrashing of the server under high concurrent load (for instance from a build server)
fields.summary: Throttling of hosting operations over SSH is broken

fields.description:
The area directly above the diff section when viewing a commit shows links to branches and labels that contain the commit. This is great functionality when there are a small number of links. But when viewing an older commit there can be hundreds of links in this section. This makes it difficult to move between the header section and the diff section.

I would suggest that the branch and label links section be collapsible (and only show one or two lines by default) or work like the other header links and show a link to "n labels/branches" with a popup window like the "n JIRA Issues" link.
fields.summary: Reduce area used for the branch details section in commits

fields.description:
See screenshot
Only happen when

Currently happen in stash.prod [https://s3.amazonaws.com/uploads.hipchat.com/10804/1341511/pcOi1tzMLvg75ef/Screen%20Shot%202015-04-28%20at%2015.10.02.png]
fields.summary: Clone Dialog mixed with the background on FF when is on top of the screen and a source file is open

fields.description:
We are on Stash 3.1.0 and we miss an option to show 'space' and 'tab' visible markers in Diff. This inhibits our ability to see whether a PR adheres to space/tab policies. 

There was a JIRA raised (https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/STASH-2998) more than 2 years ago which was closed citing preparation to source code/diff rendering refactor.

Has time come for this feature? It is long overdue.

Thanks
fields.summary: Show 'space' and 'tab' visible markers in Diff

fields.description:
# Go to the 'user directories' setting panel
# Click 'add directory', and pick one of the LDAP-related choices
# Click on the 'help' link (?) next to the heading

Expected results: help page opens
Actual results: Taken to https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/embedded.crowd.directory.configure.delegating.ldap with a 'page not found' error
fields.summary: Help link from 'create LDAP user directory' doesn't work

fields.description:
When using a *delegated* LDAP directory, users are able to change their display name and email address in the 'manage account' section.

There's no point to allowing this, and it just confuses people - the settings will be resynced when the user logs in again (STASH-2995).

This only happens with delegated LDAP directories, not 'regular' ones.

This is similar to STASH-2978 which fixed this issue for the password setting, but not the display name/email.
fields.summary: Delegated LDAP users should not be able to change email/display name when 'copy user on login' option is enabled
Support of word documents in Stash including diff

fields.description:
Currently a {{client-context-provider}} for a {{client-web-[panel,item,section]}} must return data synchronously. Support a method for providing asynchronous data instead.

Open questions:
# How does a client specify async data? (Probably returning a Promise)
# Do we show loading spinners while the data is loading? Can this be configured?
# How do we handle errors in these panels?
# Do we handle timeouts? How?

Related:
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/15280996/answers/15281927
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/14812632
fields.summary: Client Web Fragments should support async client-context-providers
Non-fast-forward message for ff-only merges reads poorly for cross-repository pull requests

fields.description:
When viewing pull request diff, file names are too long and I have to use scroll bar, which is often off page and I have to scroll down to view it.

It would be nice to make the view a split panel so I can widen it if required.
fields.summary: Diff SplitPanel

When I try to go to {color:red} "Diff to previous"{color} of my plain text file, it always shows {color:red}"This file cannot be rendered in your browser."{color}. My file's extension is {color:red}srw{color}.

However, when I copy this file, and change the extension to {color:red}txt{color}, I can see the diff properly.

I attached the file for your reference.
Thanks & Best Regards
fields.summary: Showing Diff of File with Special Extension

fields.description:
In our workflow, ideally we'd be able to designate particular files or folders as requiring additional approvals.  This way, any pull-request containing changes to such files will automatically require a higher number of reviews.

Our project has config/tertiary-srccode files which change often for which we are fine allowing for 1 reviewer.  But if something changes in our core source-code, we want to be able to automatically require an extra level of scrutiny.

So, say I want changes to anything under project/src/xyz/ to automatically require an additional approval, or even 2 additional approvals.

Another feature would be to base this based on filetype

Yet another use-case would be to require additional approvals on a PR if it included a file that was changed multiple times since completion of the last sprint

NOTE: I work for a large corporation which doesn't allow for third-party plugins to be installed without going through a lengthy approval/on-boarding process. So, we are basically limited to having this functionality in native stash.
fields.summary: Allow for pull-requests to allow for differing levels (#s) of approval based on rules

fields.description:
When updating a pull request, depending on the changes made I would sometimes like to unapprove individual reviewers such that the PR appears back in their "Reviewing" queue.

Currently when hovering over a reviewer's photo a tooltip is shown regardless of approval status. Clicking currently has no action. It would be nice if clicking popped up a tool window with an "Mark Unapproved" option and, if the person has not approved, a "Remove Reviewer" option. This tool window could then be made available for third-party plugins to place additional buttons (e.g., a "Poke" to send a review reminder).
fields.summary: Unapprove Individual Reviewers (aka reset approvals)

fields.description:
h2. Problem description:

In some cases, based on the file content (aka file encoding), Bitbucket server displays the Umlaut and other non-ASCII characters as either a diamond <?> or another character found in the Russian alphabet. The <?> is usually seen when a non UTF-8 file encoding such as Latin 1 is used without diff transcoding. The incorrect character is normally seen when diff transcoding is on.

h2. How to reproduce:

Push the attached repo to bitbucket server and view the diff between master and the german-changes branch.

h2. Things to be mindful of

# Git offers a RAW mode for some commands which can simplify line ending problems
# Encoding detection should be done once per file
# I had to pass iconv the '-c' option to force it to skip conversion of the euro sign in the file.
fields.summary: German Umlaut characters display incorrectly in diff view

fields.description:
Currently it is only possible to create pull request with a "standard" branch a a source. For our add-on we need to have an option to create pull request with either non-standard branch (non in refs/heads or refs/tags namespace) or just commitId as a source. 

Related issues with more details on why we need that is: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/STASH-7310
fields.summary: Allow to create pull request with a particular commit as a source

fields.description:
Right now I could use the following URL:

projects/PROJECT_1/repos/rep_1/commits?until=refs/heads...

to view branch history. There is no way to use non refs/heads branch or commitId as "until" value to view history starting from a particular commit or for a non-standard branch/tag.

Let user use commit SHA-1 as "until" parameter" or branch ref other than one in the refs/heads.

We need that, as new version of our SVN Mirror Add-On keeps track of unsynced commits by putting them into "refs/subgit/unsynced" namespace. 

For instance, unsynced commit could appear when user decides to mirror non-empty Git repository with a Subversion project, then, if there are branches already present in both repositories, those on the Git side will be moved to "refs/subgit/unsynced" namespace. Later user is provided with the UI where it is possible to review such branches and merge them back to repository or discard. Same situation could appear when user disables mirror and them enables it back when histories are already diverged - Git side will be moved to "refs/unsynced" namespsace then.

For that to work smoothly we need two improvements - first is the one above (show history starting from a particular commit or from non refs/heads references) and second is to let pull request use arbitrary commit or non refs/heads branch as a source (this I'll put in a separate issue).
fields.summary: Allow to view history for arbitrary commit

fields.description:
*An open source Git extension for versioning large files*

Git Large File Storage (LFS) replaces large files such as audio samples, videos, datasets, and graphics with text pointers inside Git, while storing the file contents on a remote server like GitHub.com or GitHub Enterprise.

*+Features+*

By design, every git repository contains every version of every file. But for some types of projects, this is not reasonable or even practical. Multiple revisions of a large file take up space quickly, slowing down repository operations and making fetches unwieldy.

Git LFS overcomes this limitation by storing the metadata for large files in Git and syncing the file contents to a configurable [Git LFS server|https://github.com/github/git-lfs/blob/master/docs/api.md]. Some of the key features include:

* Tight integration with Git means you don't have to change your workflow after the initial configuration.
* Large files are synced separately to a configurable Git LFS server over HTTPS, so you are not limited in where you push your Git repository.
* Large files are only synced from the server when they are checked out, so your local repository doesn't carry the weight of every version of every file when it is not needed.
* The meta data stored in Git is extensible for future use. It currently includes a hash of the contents of the file, and the file size so clients can display a progress bar while downloading or opt out of a large download.
* Clients and servers can make use of all the features of HTTPS, such as caching content locally on a CDN, resumable uploads and downloads, or performing requests in parallel for faster transfers.

*+More Info+:* https://git-lfs.github.com/
*+Source Code+:* https://github.com/github/git-lfs
fields.summary: Support Git Large File Storage (LFS) extension

fields.description:
Given a simple repository 

repo
  a/Validator.java


*Precondition*
Branches master and feature/f1. feature/f1 branches from master. File Validator.java was modified in branch feature/f1 (23f27c), and in branch master moved from a/Validator.java to a/a2/a3/Validator.java (4128b7). A pull request was successful created from feature/f1 to master.

*Error 1*
In pull request TAB "Diff" the file is shown with destination path a/a2/a3. Is this the right behaviour? But file diffs are correct shown.
!image-01.png!

But after button "View the full source of this file"
!image-02.png!
is pressed, the warning "The path "a/a2/a3/Validator.java" does not exist at revision "refs/heads/feature/f1"" is printed.
!image-03.png!

With debug and trace enabled, we can see the git commands:

{noformat}
git for-each-ref --sort=-objecttype --format=%(objecttype)%02%(refname)%02%(objectname)%02%(*objectname) refs/heads/ refs/tags/
git cat-file -t refs/heads/feature/f1:a/a2/a3/Validator.java
{noformat}

In the 2nd command, the a/a2/a3/Validator.java doesn't match to branch feature/f1.


*Error 2*
Using a merge hook (MergeRequestCheck implementation), the methode contentService.streamFile() has the same problem, which leads to an Exception:

{noformat}
com.atlassian.stash.exception.NoSuchPathException: The path "a/a2/a3/Validator.java" does not exist at revision "23f27cf991c70ee70da1a553cd1f9654776ba744"
{noformat}

Where the last commit id got by

{noformat}
String latestCommitId = mergeRequest.getPullRequest().getFromRef().getLatestChangeset();
{noformat}

The resulting git command is

{noformat}
git cat-file -p 23f27cf991c70ee70da1a553cd1f9654776ba744:a/a2/a3/Validator.java
{noformat}


These both errors are present in our production stash 2.12.1 as well as in 3.8.0.
They can be avoided by an update of the source-branch with the destination branch.
But I think the API should handle this properly.
fields.summary: In a pull request, the method contentService.streamFile(Repository, String, String, TypeAwareOutputSupplier) throws NoSuchPathException if the file was moved in the destination branch

fields.description:
If a file has greater than 10,000 lines and is then deleted the diff will never load on a pull request. 

This can be reproduced by:

# Creating a file with 10,001 lines
# Adding that file and committing it to a branch ({{add}})
# Creating a new branch from the original named {{remove}}
# Deleting that file, committing and pushing both branches
# Creating a pull request with a source of {{remove}} and destination of {{add}}
# Viewing the diff tab of the pull request will cause the request to spin because of a JS error:

JS console shows a {{Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'toString' of null}} on line 2505 of {{batch.js}}

File type does not seem to be of consequence this works on several versions of Stash.

Changing {{page.max.diff.lines=10000}} in {{stash-config.properties}} has no effect either.

fields.description:
The stash audit log doesn't log the IP address if there is an authentication failure. This makes it hard to track down auth issues:

The audit log just contains:

{noformat}
- | AuthenticationFailureEvent | - | 1428621076778 | git | {"authentication-method":"ssh"} | - | -
{noformat}

when it gets an unknown key, without a source IP.

In cases where the user/key exists in Stash, but the user has no access (or is trying to push with no write access), the access log contains the details (although there's no indication that it failed).

However when the key doesn't exist, there's nothing logged so no way to track this down. the IP (and ideally the fingerprint) should be logged

Tested on 3.6.1 and 3.8.0
fields.summary: Log source IP (and username, where possible) for ssh authentication failures

fields.description:
When a user connects to stash via ssh and runs an unsupported command, stash logs:

2015-04-10 08:56:59,668 WARN  [ssh-scm-request-handler]  c.a.s.i.s.s.SshScmRequestCommandAdapter test: Request is not supported; no handler is available

However, there's no indication of who the user is or where the request is coming from - the stash-access log only appears to be updated for requests that stash can handle.

This makes it very difficult to track down who is running these invalid commands. (In my case, there is someone running a script of some sort every few minutes, and I had to track it down with tcpdump and proxy logs...)

To reproduce:

# Set up stash with ssh access
# Run: ssh -p 7999 git@localhost 'test'

Results: the above error is logged
Expected results: I should be able to find out who is doing this invalid request, so I can get them to stop

The audit log logs this incorrectly too - it says that its an auth failure:

- | AuthenticationFailureEvent | - | 1428620817768 | git | {"authentication-method":"ssh"} | - | -

but that is wrong (authentication was successful), and doesn't help since it just logs the generic 'git' user rather than the stash user (or even an IP, although that wouldn't help in my case)

HTTP already logs this situation (404):

127.0.0.1 | http | i@1Y6DZ39x546x1332x0 | - | 2015-04-10 09:06:03,413 | "GET /wrong HTTP/1.1" | "" "Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Fedora; Linux x86_64; rv:37.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/37.0" | - | - | wma1b1 | 

Happens on 3.6.1, and I also tried the latest 3.8.0
fields.summary: Log user/source IP when unsupported ssh command is attempted

fields.description:
Pull Requests in Stash can be merged using these git commands from a client with no permissions to merge:

{code}
git branch test
git checkout test
vi newFile
git add .
git commit -m 'first commit’
git push origin test
{code}
Create pull request from 'test' to 'master'
{code}
git reset HEAD^
git push -uf origin HEAD
{code}

In this scenario the branches are technically merged back to the previous commit on master, however, form an admins perspective in Stash, it Appears that a Pull request has been merged by someone who has no permissions to do so. Some sort of message informing the admin that this is not a traditional merge and that the branch was reset would be helpful.
fields.summary: Informative comment on Pull Requests that have been Merged due to RESET HEAD^

fields.description:
It would save a lot of time and training to pass out client-side git-hooks from Stash.

Ideally, a client-side git-hook could be uploaded to a Stash repository through the web interface. Clients that clone the repository could have the git-hooks downloaded and installed automatically to integrated SourceTree clients.

An example would be utilizing a pre-push git-hook to enforce that all unit tests need to be run before pushing to a repository, as a team standard.
fields.summary: As a team administrator manage client-side hooks from Stash

fields.description:
I'm a Stash and Bamboo (5.7.2) admin in for our organization.  We have a around 150 repos and about 500 Bamboo plans.  We have Bamboo and Stash connected with an application link.

Recently I looked at the SSH tab of my own user profile and noticed I had dozens and dozens of SSH keys.  One was for my development machine (which I added long ago), and the rest had a label that is the base URL of our Bamboo instance.  Each of these keys seemed to be different.

Later, I discovered that every time I log into Bamboo and add a new "Repository" to a plan (using the "Stash" repository type and selecting the repo and branch from drop-down lists), it adds another SSH key to my account.

To me, this doesn't make much sense.  I check the account of another admin and they also had a pile of SSH keys with the same label (from the Bamboo plans they had created).

Is this expected behaviour?  It seems really strange to me.  What happens to all these plans if one of the admins leaves the organization?  Why would setting up a Bamboo plan linked to a repository create an SSH entry for the user that created the Bamboo plan?
fields.summary: Dozens of SSH keys appearing in my Stash user profile

fields.description:
Current situation:
When viewing a merge commit in Stash it is possible to selcet the commit out of the parent commits relative to which the diff is shown.

Proposal:
When using the "git show" command with a merge commit a combined diff is shown. That means that only the changes that were made during the merge are shown. It would be great if such a diff could be shown in stash aswell. This would make the review of merge commits a lot easier.
fields.summary: Diff of merge commit

fields.description:
h6. Expected Result:
Pull request Title should be the branch name and description should contain the commit messages regardless of how many commits are in the branch.
h6. Actual Results:
Pull requests created on branches with a single commit automatically populate the Title with the commit message and has a blank description. After adding a second commit to the branch, the Title is populated with the branch name and description contains the commit messages as expected.
fields.summary: Pull Request from Branch with One Commit Not Populating as Expected

fields.description:
A couple times in the past few months I've had pull requests mysteriously approve themselves.  I spoke to a co-worker this morning and she clued me in that I must have accidentally typed 'a' while not in focus of a text field.

This is concerning because there was no feedback visible on my screen to let me know I did this.  I was too far down the page to see that the Approve button had turned green.  Most other keyboard commands give visual feedback when executed, regardless of where you are on the screen.

I think the hotkey should simply be removed.  Hotkeys are best for frequent actions.  Approving a pull request is nowhere near as frequent and skipping to the next difference.

If you want to keep the hotkey, then I would recommend some sort of confirmation dialog.  Yes, it's easy to unapprove a request once you realize you've done it, but this clutters the chat history.

As originally reported here: https://twitter.com/syeberman/status/585820018128093184
fields.summary: Remove the hotkey for Approve Pull Request

fields.description: A button to checkout the source branch of a pull request in SourceTree would be very helpful for reviewing complex PR's. The action would cause SourceTree to search for repos in bookmarks matching the repository of the pull request, and either offers the user to checkout the branch in their existing git repo, or to clone the repo at that specific branch.
fields.summary: Pull Request: Checkout in SourceTree

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of May 2021|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#deebff|titleBGColor=#deebff|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone! It's been a long wait, but I have good news for you. In [Bitbucket Server 7.13|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-data-center-and-server-7-13-release-notes-1056675425.html#BitbucketDataCenterandServer7.13releasenotes-brm] we have released [Advanced repository management|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/advanced-repository-management-1064084889.html]. This feature helps to get a holistic view on all repositories in Bitbucket. It can help you find all orphaned repositories in just a few clicks. Select _Personal (deleted users)_ option in _Repositories type_ filter.

Note: We will add Repository size filter soon, so that figuring out which orphaned repositories occupy the most disk space will be easy.

To learn more about new features of Bitbucket Data Center 7.13 read the [release notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-data-center-and-server-7-13-release-notes-1056675425.html].

Cheers,
 Anton Genkin - Product Manager 
 Bitbucket Data Center
{panel}
*Original message*
h3. Summary

From [this post in Answers|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/249540/how-do-you-find-orphaned-repositories-in-stash] we found a use case in which users that are removed from Stash or deactivated in an external User Directory might leave orphan personal repositories behind that are not accessible from the UI.

We should offer sysadmins a way to view these orphaned personal repositories so they can be managed.
h3. Steps to Reproduce

Here is the scenario. I, the administrator, create a user. The user logs in and creates some repositories and only gives himself/herself access to said repositories.
 The user is now fired and the administrator (actually the LDAP synchronization task) removes the user from Stash. How does the administrator find all of the repositories that the user created?
 When I run this test, the repositories just seem to disappear. I have to know the names of the repositories to search for them and then I can add a new owner or delete them.
 I work for a large organization and this scenario could lead to many orphaned repositories, because the administrator is not privy to every employee departure and certainly would not know what repositories were created by the user.

*Scenario 1: Internal Database*
 # Create a user in the Stash Internal Database
 # Add at least [Global permissions to it|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Global+permissions]
 # Log in as the newly created user
 # Go to its profile and create a personal repo
 # As an admin user, delete the user
 # You will have created an orphan repo

*Scenario 2: External Directory*
 # Create a user in the External Directory you've got (i.e. LDAP, Crowd or JIRA)
 # Add at least [Global permissions to it|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Global+permissions]
 # Log in as the newly created user
 # Go to its profile and create a personal repo
 # As an admin of the User Directory, de-activate the user
 # You will have created an orphan repo

h3. Expected Results

The repo will still be there, but the Stash administrator will have a way to easily find repos on that situation.
h3. Actual Results

The repo will still be there, but the Stash administrator will have a way to easily find repos on that situation.

This ties back to STASH-3564 as there should be a better way to visualize/browse personal repositories
h3. Workaround

You will be able to find the orphan users/repos if you run the query below against your database:
{code:java}
select snu.name, r.slug from sta_personal_project spr, repository r, sta_normal_user snu
where spr.project_id=r.project_id and spr.owner_id=snu.user_id 
and snu.name not in 
(select u.lower_user_name 
from cwd_user u join cwd_directory d on u.directory_id = d.id 
where d.is_active='T' and u.is_active='T');
{code}
*Important:* do not change anything on your database. With the information above, as a Stash administrator, you will be able to hit the orphan profile page of that user and remove its repo. You will have to browse straight into their profile page by hitting the following URL:
{noformat}
http://<Stash_URL>/users/<username_from_query_above>
{noformat}
On this page you will be able to see all the user's orphan repos. From there, you can browse into the repo "Settings" and delete the repo on the top right button of the next screen.

If you need the deletion to be done in bulk, you can programmatically do it using the {{DELETE}} method using {{curl}}, for example, calling this [REST API in Stash|https://developer.atlassian.com/static/rest/stash/3.8.0/stash-rest.html#idp1379536].
fields.summary: Allow sysadmins to view orphaned repositories in Stash

fields.description:
When upgrading, if the installer doesn't detect a service installation, we should:
*  Warn the customer that any previously installed/custom service will still refer to their old binaries as we didn't update them. This is a dangerous situation: they should remove any previously deployed services as rebooting their server with such scripts deployed might cause damage to their Stash home
* Give the customer an option to install the service with our standard service scripts. That way, customers will be able to start a newly deployed service and that will be supported for their instance's lifetime.

This is important because [this document|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/running-bitbucket-server-as-a-linux-service-776640157.html] is not the same as what the current service script deployed by the Linux installer does.

|*Customer Story:*
  As of Stash 3.8 an upgrade workflow was introduced in the Stash installer. When using the installer and following the upgrade workflow, the installer is unable to detect and therefore update custom previously deployed Stash services on both Windows and Linux environments. 
  If a customer has a service set up previously done by our installer, the upgrade path will work and update the binaries it needs to start/stop the newly upgraded instance. Therefore, when the upgrade workflow is finished, starting/stopping Stash using the "old" (or custom services/scripts) will work normally for the operations team. 
  If the installer doesn't detect the expected service installations, however, it should warn the customers that previously installed/custom service installations will still be referring to their old binaries as we don't update them. From here we should warn them: 
- This is a dangerous situation: they should remove any previously deployed services as rebooting their server with such scripts deployed might cause damage to their Stash home or update their service scripts accordingly 
- Offer the service set up our standard service scripts. That way, customers will be able to start a newly deployed service and that will be supported for their instance's lifetime.|
fields.summary: Installer upgrade should prompt to install service

fields.description: When {{RepositoryHookService.setSettings(Repository, String, Settings)}} is called, rather than updating the existing database row for the {{Settings}} object, a new row is always created and the previous row is left orphaned. This causes the {{sta_shared_lob}} table to grow without bounds, steadily increasing database and backup size.
fields.summary: Updating repository hook settings creates new rows instead of updating existing ones

fields.description: When an anchor link is used in a markdown file, it will only work on the default (usually {{master}}) branch. This looks to be likely caused by the {{?at=refs%2Fheads%2Fbranch-name}} that's appended to the end of the URL. *Steps to reproduce* # Create a new branch. # Create a new markdown document that includes a named anchor and a link to that anchor [contents](#TOC). # Push the new branch to Stash. # Open the repository's Source page in Stash. # Switch to displaying the new branch. # Open the markdown document. # Click on the link and nothing happens, but it should jump to the anchor location. The link used is {{http://stash.company.com/projects/PROJ/repos/repo/browse/test.md?at=refs%2Fheads%2Ftest-branch#TOC?at=refs%2Fheads%2Ftest-branch}}. *Expected Result* The URL that is generated should be something along the lines of {{http://stash.company.com/projects/PROJ/repos/repo/browse/test.md?at=refs%2Fheads%2Ftest-branch#TOC}} and scroll to the appropriate location.
fields.summary: Anchor links in markdown broken when not on the default branch

fields.description:
Hi,

We write all of our Atlassian plug-ins in Scala. Since version 3.8 of Stash, our plug-ins don't work anymore because we get java.lang.NoSuchMethodError's all over the place when using the Scala library, e.g.:

java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: scala.collection.Seq.take(I)Ljava/lang/Object;

We use the provided Scala library of Stash, so we don't ship it by ourselves in the plug-in JAR. Have there been any changes related to the Scala provider plug-in in Stash 3.8? I've checked the OSGI page of Stash 3.8 and there doesn't seam to be any obvious changes:

Atlassian-Plugin-Key: com.atlassian.scala.plugins.scala-2.10-provider-plugin
Bundle-Description: This plugin provides the scala runtime for scala 2.10.3
Bundle-Version: 0.5

Any help is much appreciated!

Thanks,
Michael
fields.summary: Changes in Scala provider plug-in makes our plug-ins fail in Stash 3.8

fields.description:
If a git client balls out when the server is running it's post-receive hooks and one of the hooks print to stdout/stderr then a SIGPIP is generated.

The solution is simple : trap the pipe signal and the post hooks will be executed properly.

#!/usr/bin/env bash
#>*******************************************************
# THIS FILE WAS AUTO-GENERATED BY ATLASSIAN STASH.
# IT CONTAINS NO USER-SERVICEABLE PARTS.
#>*******************************************************
trap '' PIPE
if [[ "$OSTYPE" == "cygwin" ]]; then
    exec $(cygpath $STASH_HOOK_COORDINATOR) hooks/post-receive.d "$@" <&0 >&1 2>&2
else
    exec $STASH_HOOK_COORDINATOR hooks/post-receive.d "$@" <&0 >&1 2>&2
fi
fields.summary: post-receive hook can be interrupted

fields.description: There should be a setting per repository to put a maximum amount of branches allowable for that particular repository.
fields.summary: Restrict Amount of Branches Per Repository

fields.description:
I am developing a plugin for Atlassian Stash 3.7.0. When I am listening for PullRequestEvent, like this:
...
@EventListener
 public void anEvent(PullRequestEvent o) {
...
I noticed that the code gets called twice when a pull requested is opened. And only once when a pull request is commented.

Complete code available here:
https://github.com/tomasbjerre/pull-request-notifier-for-stash

Bug encountered in:
src/main/java/se/bjurr/prnfs/listener/PrnfsPullRequestEventListener.java
fields.summary: PullRequestAction.OPENED event fired twice

fields.description:
It would be really nice if I could add links in the git commit messages, that would actually work on the commit list or commit details in stash. 
Perhaps by permitting the full comment markdown in the commit messages, or by at least automatically make links like http://somesite/... as clickable links. Also the recognition of commit hashes or JIRA codes would be very nice.
fields.summary: Allow markdown in gitcommit messages

fields.description: If you have the side-by-side diff view enabled in Stash it can be difficult to see all of the code changes without scrolling horizontally in the document. It would be nice to be able to resize the column containing the file tree (not just collapse it) as well as altering the ratio between the "before" and "after" commit columns.
fields.summary: Include the ability to resize the columns when reviewing a pull request in Stash

fields.description:
*Now* when a user creates a pull request - last commit comment gets into PR Title's field. Since into PR further processing can be involved a broader community, that just developers, that last commit may not always be informative enough for all the people. Sometimes it is better to have a branch name as a default title for PR.

For some teams, for sure, last commit is a preferable solution.

*Suggestion* is to make a repository option for Default Pull Request Title: 

-Last Commit
-Branch Name

Thank you,
Roman.
fields.summary: Option: Default Title for Pull Request

fields.description: Please display the last commit ID, commit date and commit message in the Stash file listing.
fields.summary: Display last commit ID, commit date and commit message for Folder and Files

fields.description:
This bit of code at the top of stash.diy-backup.postgresql.sh doesn;t work correctly. 



{noformat}
# Make use of PostgreSQL 9.3+ options if available
psql_version="$(psql --version | awk '{print $3}')"
if [[ ${psql_version//./} -ge 930 ]]; then
    PG_PARALLELL="-j 5"
    PG_SNAPSHOT_OPT="--no-synchronized-snapshots"
fi
{noformat}


Because my version of psql is 9.2.10 it determined that I would be able to use PG_PARALLELL="-j5" because the if condition compares 9210 again 930 and finds it greater.

This caused the backup to crash in the middle and after canceling the backup with the token, it went into a further maintenance mode for which I could not find a token, so I had to restart Stash to get ti working again.  Not yet clear if there was data loss.

As a workaround I will comment out this section of code
fields.summary: postgres version not properly detected

fields.description:
It would be nice to have the timestamp that an SSH key was added to Stash available. This would allow the following benefits:

* Find older SSH keys that may need to be replaced
* Provide the ability to filter the REST API for SSH keys to only show keys added after/before a timestamp
* Order keys from the SSH REST API by created date
fields.summary: Add timestamp to SSH key REST API

fields.description:
The page at https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Stash+3.8+release+notes says "Note that Internet Explorer doesn't support Ctrl-clicking, unfortunately".  That is 100% unture.  I have had IE apps for over a decade that I developed that specifically take different actions for clicking, Ctrl+clicking, and Shift+clicking.  This functionality has worked from IE 4 through IE 11 in my apps.

I don't know how the develper came to the conclusion that he or she did, but one solution is to look for a control key event and no shift key event while inside a click event handler.  Yes, there may not be a control click combo handler, but expecting such is lazy.
fields.summary: False excuse

fields.description:
When Stash is configured to use SSL and the base URL is set to use HTTPS, the label of the dropdown menu when selecting from SSH or HTTP should be updated to HTTPS.

For example, in the screenshot below, the highlighted HTTP should be changed to HTTPS.

!Screen Shot 2015-03-30 at 3.06.53 PM.png|thumbnail!

Note: the URL that is generated is correct, this is to align the label of HTTP to show that HTTPS is in use.
fields.summary: Update the label of the clone dropdown to show HTTPS when in use

fields.description: It looks like the update behavior is that only licensed users will  be listed with the mention, but this doesn't take the limit far enough.  Users who don't have permissions to a project shouldn't be available for mentions in the context of that project.  For us this is a security issue, for most, this is still bad UI.  It'll only create confusion and concern from a security perspective (The inevitable question will be does this person have access to our project?  Why do they show up here?).  This also creates the possibility of leaking sensitive client information.  We're a hosting multiple clients with this application and it would allow them to search for each other, which is a problem for us.
fields.summary: Limit @ mention list to authorized users

fields.description:
Hi Atlassian, 

We've noticed "My pull requests" will only display up to 10 pull request.  This has been verified on the following systems: Chromium and Firefox on Linux, Firefox on Windows and Chrome on Mac OS.

This is problematic because the majority of our developers work across multiple projects and repositories which make the alternative of drilling into a specific repo's to view pull requests very cumbersome.

Thanks,
Chris
fields.summary: My Pull Requests limited to 10
